items.title: Forum software NodeBB joins the fediverse
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- NodeBB, a major forum software provider, joins the [fediverse](https://techcrunch.com/2024/06/25/welcome-to-the-fediverse-your-guide-to-mastodon-threads-bluesky-and-more/).
- The fediverse includes decentralized apps like [Mastodon](https://techcrunch.com/2023/07/24/what-is-mastodon/), [Pixelfed](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/14/decentralized-instagram-alternative-pixelfed-launches-mobile-apps/), and [PeerTube](https://techcrunch.com/2023/10/11/wordpress-com-blogs-can-now-be-followed-on-mastodon-and-other-federated-platforms/).
- NodeBB co-founder Julian Lam had the idea in mid-2023 to connect NodeBB forums to each other, leading to the decision to adopt the [ActivityPub](https://techcrunch.com/2024/06/25/all-threads-users-can-now-share-to-the-open-social-web-aka-the-fediverse/) protocol for decentralization.
- Funding from the [NLNet Foundation](https://nlnet.nl/commonsfund/) helped expedite the implementation of ActivityPub in NodeBB.
- New forums created with NodeBB will be federated automatically; existing forums can interact with other ActivityPub-powered software.
- The federation feature is built into NodeBB's core as of version 4.0, not just as an add-on, differing from [Discourse](https://meta.discourse.org/t/activitypub-plugin/266794).
- NodeBB does not track usage numbers but had 4,582 downloads last week, indicating a steady interest.

items.title: Samsung Unpacked 2025: Here’s how to watch and what we expect
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- The Samsung Unpacked event is scheduled for Wednesday at 10 a.m. PT.
- The event will be streamed on Samsung’s website and their YouTube channel.
- Preorders come with a $50 Samsung store credit for reservations ahead of the event.
- The Galaxy S25 line will be announced, including models S25, S25+, and S25 Ultra.
- Rumors suggest a slimmer design and the inclusion of the Snapdragon 8 Elite chip.
- AI features will be highlighted, aiming to differentiate from Google’s offerings.

items.title: Meta will soon let you link your WhatsApp account with Instagram and Facebook
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Meta announced integration allowing users to link WhatsApp with Accounts Center for managing Facebook and Instagram accounts.
- Users can cross-post WhatsApp Status as Stories on Instagram and Facebook.
- Single Sign On feature will enable logging into multiple apps with the same account.
- Integration is optional and off by default; messages remain end-to-end encrypted.
- WhatsApp integration will be rolled out globally over several months, with user notifications in WhatsApp settings.

items.title: IMDb founder steps down as CEO after 35 years
items.author: Col Needham, Nikki Santoro
items.summary:
- IMDb's founder, Col Needham, steps down as CEO after 35 years.
- Nikki Santoro, previously COO since 2021, is appointed as the new CEO, making her the first woman to hold the position.
- Needham will transition to a new role as executive chair.
- Santoro has been with IMDb since 2016 and has a history of leadership at Amazon, Microsoft, and The Weather Channel.

items.title: Anthropic plans to release a ‘two-way’ voice mode for Claude
items.author: Dario Amodei
items.summary:
- Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei announced plans for a ‘two-way’ voice mode for the chatbot Claude.
- A new memory feature will allow Claude to remember users and past conversations.
- Anthropic expects to release “smarter” AI models soon due to a surge in demand.
- The company has raised $13.7 billion but reported significant losses last year, prompting ongoing fundraising efforts.

items.title: UK plans ‘digital wallet’ for driver’s licenses and other ID, plus a chatbot powered by OpenAI
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- The UK government plans to launch a secure digital wallet for government-issued credentials and a chatbot called ‘chat-uk’ powered by OpenAI.
- Initial cards will include a virtual driver’s license and a veteran card; the wallet is set to launch later this year.
- Testing of the chatbot has begun, despite some issues such as unexpected responses during trials.
- The GOV.UK portal is expected to go live in 2025, while the chatbot is currently being tested by users.
- The digital wallet aims to provide secure storage for documents and improve online age verification.
- Security features will utilize smartphone technology, including facial recognition, to enhance safety.
- There are no plans to make digital services mandatory, but the government aims to make them attractive to users.

items.title: Mistral AI plans IPO
items.author: Arthur Mensch
items.summary:
- Mistral AI, a French AI lab, is planning an initial public offering (IPO).
- CEO Arthur Mensch confirmed the plans during an interview at the World Economic Forum in Davos.
- The company intends to expand its presence in the Asia-Pacific region with a new office in Singapore, while continuing to grow in Europe and the U.S.
- Mistral was founded in 2023 by former researchers from Google DeepMind and Meta.
- The company has raised approximately $1.14 billion from notable investors like Andreessen Horowitz and General Catalyst, and was valued at around $6 billion.

items.title: Toronto school district says 40 years of student data stolen in PowerSchool breach
items.summary:
- Toronto District School Board (TDSB) reports a data breach affecting 40 years of student data due to the recent PowerSchool breach.
- The breach affects all students enrolled from September 1985 to December 2024, impacting approximately 240,000 students.
- Compromised data includes names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, and recent contact information for parents and guardians.
- PowerSchool claims to have received confirmation from hackers that the stolen data was deleted, though no further details have been provided.

items.title: Qomodo raises $13.9M to expand BNPL for Italy’s main-street retailers
items.author: Gianluca Cocco, Gaetano de Maio
items.summary:
- Qomodo, a Milan-based payment methods aggregator, raised €13.5 million ($13.9 million) in Series A funding, co-led by RTP Global and LMDV Capital.
- The company aims to expand its Buy Now Pay Later (BNPL) model for physical retailers, with a focus on improving cash flow for small businesses.
- Qomodo has raised a total of €48 million ($49.6 million), serving around 2,500 physical merchants primarily in Italy.

items.title: HPE investigating security breach after hacker claims theft of sensitive data
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- HPE is investigating a data breach after the hacker IntelBroker claimed to have stolen sensitive information.
- The hacker claims the data includes product source code, private GitHub repositories, and access keys to HPE services.
- HPE activated cyber response protocols immediately after becoming aware of the claims on January 16.

items.title: MoneyHash, which provides single access to payment services in MENA, banks $5.2M
items.summary:
- Egypt’s MoneyHash raised $5.2 million to expand its payment orchestration platform for larger enterprises.
- This funding comes about a year after a previous $4.5 million seed round in February 2024, totaling over $12 million since its inception in early 2021.
- The company targets e-commerce and various industries, aiming to simplify complex payment processes across the Middle East and Africa with over 300 pre-integrated APIs.

items.title: Karmen secures $9.4 million for its revenue-based financing products
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- French startup [Karmen](https://www.karmen.io/) raises €9 million ($9.4 million) in a funding round to enhance its instant financing for SMEs.
- Round led by Seventure Partners with additional debt from Financière Arbevel and Bpifrance.
- Karmen has served around 600 companies, providing loans ranging from €20,000 to €3 million, with an average loan amount of €200,000.
- The company utilizes a data-driven approach and risk assessment tools, including AI, to enhance loan evaluation and minimize repayment risks.

items.title: President Trump signs exec order to make Musk’s DOGE commission more official
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- President Trump signed an executive order to make the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) more official.
- The U.S. Digital Service (USDS) is renamed to U.S. DOGE Service (USDS), aimed at enhancing government technology.
- DOGE Teams will be formed within federal agencies to implement Trump's DOGE plan, focusing on software modernization.
- A temporary organization for DOGE will be established, with operations set to end by July 4, 2026.
- Three lawsuits have been filed questioning the legality of the DOGE commission under the Federal Advisory Committee Act (FACA).
- Elon Musk proposed DOGE could cut the federal budget by $2 trillion but has since revised that estimate to reflect political realities.

items.title: Trump signs exec order delaying TikTok enforcement action for 75 days
items.summary:
- President Trump signed an executive order to extend TikTok's service in the U.S. for 75 days.
- The order instructs agencies to protect national security while allowing TikTok to remain operational.
- The U.S. Attorney General is directed not to enforce the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act (PAFACA) during this period.
- The act effectively banned TikTok in the U.S. as of January 19.
- This move follows a U.S. Supreme Court decision to uphold the PAFACA, which was enacted with bipartisan support during the Biden administration.

items.title: President Trump repeals Biden’s AI executive order
items.summary:
- On his first day in office, President Donald Trump revoked a 2023 executive order by Joe Biden aimed at mitigating AI risks.
- The revoked order directed NIST to create guidance to help companies identify and fix biases in AI models.
- Critics of the order, aligned with Trump, claimed its reporting requirements were burdensome and infringed on trade secrets.

items.title: UK to unveil ‘Humphrey’ assistant for civil servants with other AI plans to cut bureaucracy
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- The U.K. government announced plans for AI assistants to improve public services and reduce bureaucracy, alongside a new AI tool named ‘Humphrey’.  
- The formal unveiling of these plans will occur at a press conference led by the Department of Science, Innovation and Technology (DSIT).  
- The government spends approximately £23 billion annually on technology, aiming to redeploy these funds more effectively.  
- ‘Humphrey’ is designed to ease civil servants' workloads, with applications like ‘Consult’, ‘Parlex’, ‘Minute’, ‘Redbox’, and ‘Lex’.  
- The initiative targets efficiency in public services, potentially saving £45 billion annually by streamlining outdated processes.  
- Questions remain regarding data protection and the reliability of AI recommendations, especially in cross-department collaboration.

items.title: OpenAI’s agent tool may be nearing release
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- OpenAI may soon release an AI tool called Operator that can control PCs and perform tasks autonomously.
- Developer Tibor Blaho suggests that evidence points to a January release date for Operator.
- Leaked information indicates Operator can write code, book travels, and has mixed reliability in tasks, scoring 38.1% in benchmarks compared to humans' 72.4%.
- Concerns have been raised regarding safety evaluations of AI agents as competitors emerge in the market, projected to be worth $47.1 billion by 2030.

items.title: Friend delays shipments of its AI companion pendant
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Friend, a startup, has delayed the shipment of its AI-powered necklace until Q3 2025.
- Originally planned for Q1 2025, co-founder Avi Schiffman cited the need for further refinements before manufacturing can begin.
- The company raised $8.5 million and previously spent $1.8 million on the domain name Friend.com, which hosted an experimental AI chat platform.

items.title: US safety regulators expand Ford hands-free driving tech investigation
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) upgraded its investigation into Ford's BlueCruise system following two fatal crashes involving Mustang Mach E vehicles.
- Approximately 129,222 Ford Mustang Mach E vehicles have the BlueCruise system, which is now under an engineering analysis to assess its limitations in detecting stationary vehicles.
- BlueCruise debuted in 2021 and uses advanced technology for hands-free driving, but NHTSA found it may not perform well in detecting stationary objects at high speeds or poor visibility conditions.

items.title: At the Microsoft Excel World Championship, selfies and a ‘hype’ tunnel
items.summary:
- The Microsoft Excel World Championship took place in December 2024 in Las Vegas, featuring 12 contestants solving complex Excel puzzles.
- The event attracted around 400 attendees and was live-streamed on ESPN3 alongside other competitions.
- The champion, a financial consultant from Toronto, won a $5,000 prize and a wrestling-style championship belt.
- The organizers aim to increase the prize pool to $1 million with more sponsorship and viewership in the future.

items.title: Flipboard’s new app Surf adds its own video feed, too
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Flipboard's new app, Surf, introduces a video feed following the TikTok ban.
- Surf's video feed combines trending video posts from Bluesky and those tagged with #SkyTok.
- The company plans to personalize the feed based on users' Bluesky Following timelines.
- Flipboard CEO Mike McCue emphasizes the power of custom feeds in social networking.
- Surf is currently in beta with a signup list for testers.
- The app allows the creation of various video feeds, such as a BookTok feed with relevant hashtags.
- Surf can access content from multiple networks including YouTube and Mastodon.

items.title: DeepSeek claims its reasoning model beats OpenAI’s o1 on certain benchmarks
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek has released its reasoning model DeepSeek-R1, claiming it performs as well as OpenAI’s o1 on certain benchmarks.
- R1 is available on [Hugging Face](https://huggingface.co/deepseek-ai/DeepSeek-R1) under an MIT license, allowing commercial use.
- DeepSeek claims R1 surpasses o1 on benchmarks AIME, MATH-500, and SWE-bench Verified.
- The model has 671 billion parameters but distilled versions range from 1.5 billion to 70 billion parameters.
- R1 is available via DeepSeek’s API, priced 90%-95% cheaper than OpenAI’s similar offerings.
- It has limitations due to being a Chinese model, consequently avoiding politically sensitive topics.
- The release follows the Biden administration's proposed export restrictions on AI technologies to China.

items.title: RedNote, Flip, Clapper and Likee claim the top of the App Store as TikTok comes back online
items.summary:
- TikTok has resumed services after a day-long ban, but competitors like RedNote (Xiaohongshu), Clapper, and Flip have surged in popularity.
- RedNote retained the No. 1 spot in the U.S. App Store, adding 700,000 new users amid TikTok's outage.
- Despite TikTok being back, it remains unavailable for download on app stores due to legalities, reflecting a shift towards alternative apps.
- Clapper and Likee are ranked 4th and 2nd respectively in the App Store, with significant increases in downloads post-TikTok ban.
- The app Flip, which focuses on social commerce, also saw significant growth, securing the 10th spot on the U.S. App Store.
- VPN apps experienced a spike in downloads as users attempted to bypass the TikTok ban, although their efforts were largely unsuccessful.

items.title: Meta confirms it will keep fact-checkers outside the U.S. ‘for now’
items.summary:
• Meta plans to maintain its fact-checking program outside the U.S. for the time being.
• Nicola Mendelsohn indicated the program may be expanded in the future but remains unchanged for now.
• The company faces potential challenges in implementing its new program, especially in Europe due to regulations like the Digital Services Act.

items.title: Here are the types of AI companies enterprise VCs want to back in 2025
items.author: Becca Szkutak
items.summary:
- The AI startup market is diverse, with subsectors attracting VC interest in 2025.
- VCs are focusing on AI solutions for specific enterprise tasks rather than just features.
- Important areas include business friction reduction, cybersecurity, reliability, and AI infrastructure investment.

items.title: Metropolis to Acquire Oosto for $125 Million Amid AI Landscape Changes
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Metropolis is acquiring Oosto (formerly AnyVision) for $125 million, significantly less than the $380 million raised by Oosto in previous investments.
- The deal follows Oosto's period of struggles, including lost partnerships and controversies surrounding its surveillance technologies.
- The acquisition will potentially enable Metropolis to enhance its AI-powered parking solutions, having raised $1.7 billion in recent financing for growth.

items.title: Blinkit signals costly battle ahead in Indian quick commerce market
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Blinkit aims to reach 2,000 dark stores by December 2025, ahead of its previous timeline.
- The company reported losses of 103 crore rupees ($11.9 million) in Q3FY25 as it expanded its store network.
- Competition in quick commerce is intensifying, with rivals like Zepto and Flipkart also rapidly expanding.

items.title: X is rolling out a dedicated vertical video feed for US users
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Social network X is launching a dedicated vertical video feed for U.S. users to respond to the removal of ByteDance apps from U.S. app stores.
- A new video tab will be added to the app’s bottom bar to provide quick access to video content.
- The rollout starts today, with X emphasizing an immersive new home for videos in a recent announcement.
- Users can already scroll through short videos, but this tab will offer a dedicated section for video content.
- The company has focused on video experiences recently, including launching a standalone TV app.
- Competitors like Meta and Bluesky are also introducing new video features and apps to capitalize on TikTok's troubles.

items.title: How African VC firm Oui Capital returned its first fund with Moniepoint’s unicorn exit
items.author: Tage Kene-Okafor
items.summary:
• Oui Capital returned its $4 million debut fund after selling shares in Moniepoint.
• Initial investment of $150,000 in Moniepoint generated an $8 million return.
• Moniepoint raised $110 million at a $1 billion valuation last October, allowing Oui Capital to repay the fund and generate future profits for investors.
• Oui Capital is among a few VC firms in Africa to successfully return their first fund, emphasizing the potential of early-stage fintech investments.
• Other portfolio companies include Duplo, Maad, and Matta, and Oui Capital has two funds with a total of 22 startups.

items.title: Bluesky launches a custom feed for vertical videos
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Bluesky introduces a custom feed for vertical videos, allowing users to see trending videos in the explore tab.
- Users can pin the video feed to their home screen for easier access and can swipe up to view more content.
- The app recently surpassed 28 million users as it capitalizes on user shifts related to TikTok's availability issues and the launch of similar features by other platforms like X.

items.title: How to stream Donald Trump’s Inauguration Day 2025
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Donald Trump will take the presidential oath on January 20, 2025, at noon ET in Washington, D.C.
- The inauguration can be streamed live on various platforms, including cable services and streaming apps that provide access to major networks like ABC, CBS, CNN, and more.
- The expected lineup includes attendance from Joe Biden, Congress members, and tech leaders like Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos. Carrie Underwood will perform 'America the Beautiful.'

items.title: From recruiting for Palantir to landing a plane on Highway 85: meet defense tech’s wildest power broker
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- In 2023, recruiter Peterson Conway VIII was fired from Fuse for inappropriate behavior but was later reinstated.
- He has worked with companies like Palantir, Mach Industries, and currently heads talent at venture firm A*.
- Conway is known for unconventional recruiting methods, including offering flights in his private plane and sharing fascinating personal stories.
- He actively recruits candidates for defense tech startups, contributing to a surge in defense tech funding.
- Conway's unique storytelling and approach have garnered him a reputation as a genius but also as a liability.

items.title: AI Benchmarking Organization Criticized for Delayed Disclosure of OpenAI Funding
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Epoch AI, a nonprofit, revealed on December 20 its funding from OpenAI for the FrontierMath benchmark.
- Allegations of non-transparency arose as many contributors were unaware of OpenAI's involvement until public disclosure.
- Epoch AI admitted to communication failures but asserted that the benchmark's integrity remained intact despite OpenAI's access to problem sets.
- Associate director Tamay Besiroglu acknowledged a mistake in transparency and emphasized the importance of disclosing funding sources to contributors.
- Concerns about the potential impact on FrontierMath's reputation as an objective benchmark were raised on social media.

items.title: The Pentagon says AI is speeding up its ‘kill chain’
items.summary:
- Leading AI developers are collaborating with the U.S. military to enhance efficiency without enabling lethal actions.
- AI is providing the Pentagon with a significant advantage in threat identification and analysis, according to Dr. Radha Plumb.
- The Pentagon's use of generative AI in planning and strategy may push Silicon Valley to relax existing usage policies for military applications.

items.title: Meta announces a new video editing app called Edits
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Meta introduced a new video editing app named Edits after CapCut was removed from app stores due to the TikTok ban.
- The app is set to launch in February 2025 for iOS with an Android version to follow.
- Features include creative tools, a tab for inspiration and ideas, sharing drafts, and insights on video performance on Instagram.
- Designed primarily for creators rather than casual users.
- Previously, Meta launched Instagram Reels after TikTok's ban in India, indicating its strategy to capitalize on market gaps.

items.title: TikTok is restoring service in the US
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok is restoring service in the US after temporarily going dark due to a law prompting potential restrictions.
- The company's restoration comes after President Trump provided clarity that service providers would not face penalties.
- The app had stopped functioning and was removed from Apple and Google Play stores before this announcement.
- Trump indicated plans for a joint venture involving US ownership to keep TikTok operating in the US.

items.title: TikTok is restoring service in the US
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok is resuming service in the US after going dark for over 12 hours.
- The company thanked President Trump for providing clarity to service providers regarding liabilities.
- A law that could have led to the app's ban was set to take effect, but Trump announced an executive order to delay it.
- TikTok's app had temporarily disappeared from app stores but was back for some users by the time the announcement was made.
- Trump suggested a potential joint venture for TikTok that would involve US ownership.

items.title: TikTok goes dark in the US
items.author: Kyle Wiggers, Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok has been banned in the U.S. due to a federal law, and users started receiving notifications around 10:30 p.m. Eastern on Saturday.
- The app is no longer available in the Apple and Google Play stores, with TikTok stating, "Sorry, TikTok isn’t available right now."
- TikTok is hopeful for a resolution with President-elect Trump indicating he will work towards reinstating it, urging users to stay tuned.
- The law requiring TikTok’s owner ByteDance to sell the app or face a ban was passed by bipartisan majorities in Congress and signed by President Biden last April.
- TikTok indicated it could go dark if no definitive statement was made by the Biden administration, which responded by calling TikTok’s actions a stunt.
- Trump has suggested he may delay the ban and negotiate terms possibly involving a sale or partnership, creating uncertainty around TikTok’s long-term future.

items.title: Trump says he will delay TikTok ban, suggests a joint venture with US ownership
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok went dark in the US on Saturday but may return soon.
- President-elect Trump announced plans to issue an executive order to delay the TikTok ban for a potential deal to protect national security.
- Trump proposed a joint venture that would give the US 50% ownership.
- Bipartisan legislation requires ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban.
- The Supreme Court upheld the law before Trump’s inauguration.
- TikTok indicated a need for clarity before continuing operations; Trump aims to resume the app's functionality before the order is issued.

items.title: Employees of Failed Startups Face Increased Risk of Data Theft via Old Google Logins
items.author: Dylan Ayrey
items.summary:
- Security researcher Dylan Ayrey highlighted the risk of stolen personal data for employees of failed startups due to a Google OAuth vulnerability.
- Malicious hackers can acquire defunct domains and use them to access cloud software tied to former employees, potentially gaining access to sensitive information such as Social Security numbers.
- Ayrey tested the vulnerability by purchasing a failed startup's domain and accessing various software platforms including ChatGPT, Slack, and an HR system with sensitive data.
- Google initially dismissed the issue but later reopened the bug report and acknowledged the risk after Ayrey's talk at ShmooCon, awarding him a $1,337 bounty.

items.title: AI isn’t very good at history, new paper finds
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- A new paper reveals that AI struggles with high-level history exams, specifically tested on GPT-4, Meta’s Llama, and Google’s Gemini.
- The benchmark, Hist-LLM, uses the Seshat Global History Databank for accuracy assessment, with GPT-4 Turbo scoring only 46%.
- Researchers note LLMs lack depth in historical understanding and are biased towards more prominent historical data, affecting their performance on nuanced questions.

items.title: Apple lists all apps it removed alongside TikTok in the U.S.
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Apple issued a statement listing apps removed due to the TikTok shutdown.
- Affected apps include TikTok, CapCut, Lemon8, and Marvel Snap.
- The removal is due to the Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act, effective January 19, 2025.
- Users in the U.S. won’t receive updates or be able to download these apps.
- The Supreme Court upheld the law that prompted the app removals.
keywords: Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Controlled Applications Act

items.title: TikTok goes dark in the US
items.author: Kyle Wiggers, Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok has been banned in the U.S. following a federal law, rendering it inaccessible for millions of Americans.
- The ban was enacted around 10:30 p.m. Eastern, and the app was also removed from Apple and Google Play stores.
- TikTok suggests the ban may be temporary and has expressed hope for a resolution with President-elect Donald Trump once he takes office.
- The ban stems from bipartisan legislation requiring TikTok's owner, ByteDance, to sell the app amid concerns over Chinese surveillance.
- The Supreme Court upheld the law before the ban was enacted, leaving its implementation to the next administration.
- Alternative Chinese-owned apps like RedNote and Lemon8 have gained popularity as users search for alternatives.

items.title: Perplexity AI submits bid to merge with TikTok
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- Perplexity AI has submitted a bid to merge with TikTok US amid a potential ban of the app in the US.
- The bid aims to create a new entity that combines Perplexity, TikTok US, and new equity partners, allowing investors in ByteDance to retain their equity.
- A law requiring ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban is set to take effect on January 19, the last day of President Biden's term.
- President-elect Trump may grant TikTok a 90-day extension to avoid the ban, while TikTok states it could 'go dark' without assurances from the Biden administration.
- Despite interest from multiple buyers, ByteDance maintains it does not intend to sell TikTok, viewing the merger proposal as a potential workaround.

items.title: FTC says partnerships like Microsoft-OpenAI raise antitrust concerns
items.summary:
- The FTC issued a report on January 18, 2025, highlighting competitive issues in big tech partnerships with generative AI developers, specifically mentioning Microsoft-OpenAI and Amazon-Google with Anthropic.
- FTC Chair Lina Khan stated these partnerships could create lock-in effects, deprive startups of AI inputs, and disclose sensitive information, undermining fair competition.
- The report raises concerns about cloud service providers' influence on AI development, access to computing resources, increased switching costs, and unfair access to sensitive information.

items.title: What we know about the TikTok ban
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- The U.S. Supreme Court upheld a law that will prohibit TikTok in the U.S., effectively banning the app starting Sunday.
- American users are transitioning to RedNote, a Chinese app, which has surged in popularity and is now the No. 1 free app on the U.S. App Store.
- Duolingo reports a 216% increase in U.S. users learning Mandarin as TikTok users seek alternatives amid the impending ban.

items.title: Once high-flying proptech startups Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are the latest to struggle
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo, Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are recent casualties in the struggling proptech sector.
- Investment in U.S. real estate startups dropped from $11.1 billion in 2021 to $3.7 billion in 2022.
- Divvy Homes is being acquired by Maymont Homes, a division of Brookfield Properties, amid ongoing layoffs.
- EasyKnock shut down after facing multiple lawsuits and being declared insolvent.
- Both companies struggled due to rising interest rates hindering their business models of purchasing homes.

items.title: DOJ confirms arrested US Army soldier is linked to AT&T and Verizon hacks
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- U.S. Army soldier Cameron John Wagenius arrested on December 20 for unlawfully transferring confidential phone records.
- Arrest tied to a massive theft of phone records from AT&T and Verizon linked to breaches at Snowflake.
- Wagenius faces charges related to earlier indictments of hackers Connor Moucka and John Binns, involving significant data theft from multiple companies.
- Prosecutors confirmed overlapping evidence and legal issues related to the cases.
- Arrest publicized after Wagenius claimed access to sensitive call logs as part of extortion threats.
- He remains in custody in Washington state after a detention order issued on January 8.

items.title: TikTok says it will go dark Sunday unless Biden offers ‘definitive statement’
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok claims it may go dark on January 19 unless President Biden provides definitive reassurances against a ban.
- The Supreme Court upheld a law that could effectively ban TikTok unless ByteDance sells the app, which they refuse to do.
- The Biden administration has not changed its position, leaving TikTok's future uncertain as the incoming Trump administration is expected to address the issue.

items.title: How victims of PowerSchool’s data breach helped each other investigate ‘massive’ hack
items.summary:
- On January 7, PowerSchool notified that many schools were victims of a data breach discovered on December 28.
- Hackers accessed sensitive data including Social Security numbers and medical records from over 60 million students and 18,000 schools.
- Romy Backus, from American School of Dubai, led the investigation to determine the extent of the breach for her school.
- School workers utilized email listservs for information sharing, leading to a collaborative response to understand the breach's impact.
- Backus developed a guide detailing the breach and shared it with other PowerSchool administrators, which went viral within the community.
- The PowerSchool incident highlighted the need for better information sharing in the education sector regarding cybersecurity.
